document.docAuthor: Neal, Lenka, Brasier, Madeleine J. & Wiklund, Helena
document.docTitle: Macellicephala macintoshi Neal & Brasier & Wiklund 2018, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Six new species of Macellicephala (Annelida: Polynoidae) from the Southern Ocean and south Atlantic with re-description of type species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Six new species of Macellicephala (Annelida: Polynoidae) from the Southern Ocean and south Atlantic with re-description of type species

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Macellicephala mirabilis in
Pettibone (1976) : 10
, p. 12: Fig. 3a–e .

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined: Holotype and paratype , both specimens of McIntosh (1905), originally BMNH 1924 : 7: 21: 12, South Africa ( Cape of Good Hope),
540–900 m
depth
. Holotype retains original designation BMNH 1924: 7: 21: 12, paratype newly designated as NHMUK. 2018.25345.

Description (based on holotype ).
Holotype 25 mm long, 6.5 mm wide including parapodia and 2 mm wide excluding parapodia; with 18 segments (segment 1 = tentacular segment); body dorsoventrally flattened, tapering anteriorly and posteriorly. Colour in alcohol deep purple dorsally ( Fig. 5A ) and yellow ventrally, prostomium without pigmentation, only ceratophore of median antenna with blotches of purple pigment.

Prostomium bilobed with deep anterior notch; prostomial lobes moderately extended with tapering to somewhat angular anterior margin ( Fig. 2B , Fig. 5B ). Frontal filaments short, slender, extending from tapering lobes, medially inserted ( Fig. 2B , Fig. 5B ). Eyes absent. Facial tubercle large, with three distinct, inflated pads ( Fig. 2B , Fig. 5D ). Ceratophore of median antenna prominent, but relatively short (much shorter than prostomial lobes), cylindrical, inserted posteromedially on prostomium (near the base of anterior notch); style of median antenna missing ( Fig. 2B , Fig. 5B ). Palps smooth, distally tapering, relatively short (extending to segment 3).

Tentaculophores prominent, of equal size, cylindrical, inserted laterally to prostomium, achaetous; styles missing ( Fig. 2B , Fig. 5B ). Pharynx not observed. Second segment with elytrophores, biramous parapodia, chaetae and ventral cirri.
Nine pairs of prominent, bulbous elytrophores, on segments 2, 4, 5, 7, 9, 11, 13, 15 and 17; all elytra missing. Dorsal ridges absent.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5.
Macellicephala macintoshi
sp. nov.
(holotype, BMNH 1924: 7: 21: 12): A) specimen in dorsal view; B) detail of prostomium and anterior end in dorsal view; C) cirrigerous and elytragerous parapodia; D) detail of anterior end with trilobed facial tubercule (arrows); E) ventral view with nephridial papillae on segments 10–12 marked by arrows. Scale bars: A) 3.5 mm; B) 500 µm; C); 250 µm; D) 1 mm and E) 2 mm.

FIGURE 6.
Macellicephala macintoshi
sp. nov.
(holotype, BMNH 1924: 7: 21: 12): A) example of mid body parapodium; B) detail of notochaetae; C–F) examples of neurochaetae; G) example of slender lower neurochaetae. Scale bars: A) 500 µm: B) 300 µm; C–D) 50 µm; E) 20 µm; F) 150 µm; G) 100 µm.

TABLE 2. Comparison of characters of all known
Macellicephala
species based on the examination of representatives of species described in this study and literature survey for other species.

tr.td: distinct purple and rusty brown stripes on
relatively slender, with faint serration across convex side
long, slender, shaft smooth; with shallow interlocking spines
short, straw-coloured, shaft with horizontal striation; with
distinct interlocking spines on one side
stout, with 2 rows of spines along one side and blunt tips
long, stout, horizontally serrated across convex side
all elytra present, firmly attached, very
relatively slender, with distinct, widely spaced serration on
both margins, distally with rounded tip
relatively slender, with faint transverse spinous rows and
slender, smooth or with faint indications of spinous rows,
stout, with blunt tips; shorter ones appearing smooth; longer
prostomium with 2 pairs of large mounds
slightly stouter than neurochaetae, relatively long, distal half
with faint transverse serration, tips smooth, quite blunt
stouter than neurochaetae, clear, fragile, smooth or with faint
indications of spinous rows, with blunt tips

subSubSection.paragraph: ? Information not given in the description, neither it can be estimated from the drawings or it is stated as not observed due to poor condition of the specimen
§ - re-description given by Pettibone (1976) is based on several specimens, which likely represent different species, revision is needed

* Wu and Wang (1987) stated that facial tubercule is absent in
M. australis
, however large trilobed facial tubercule can be clearly seen depicted in their drawing (p.26, Fig. 9 )

# In original description by McIntosh (1885) and accompanying drawing, the frontal filaments were clearly present in this specimen, however by the time of Pettibone's re-description as well as our recent examination of this specimen, these filaments must have fallen off as they are no longer present. Based on the drawing of McIntosh, these filaments were inserted on the inner margin of anterior lobes.

Remarks. Specimens assigned here to
M. macintoshi
sp. nov.
were previously considered to belong to
Macellicephala mirabilis
by both McIntosh (1905) and Pettibone (1976) . New species clearly differs from the holotype of
M. mirabilis
by having much shorter, tapering to somewhat angular prostomial lobes ( Fig. 2B ), deeppurple coloration of dorsum, possession of massive tri-lobed facial tubercule and extremely short ventral cirri. See also Remarks under
M. mirabilis
and Table 2 .

In addition, there appears to be confusion about the locality of specimens assigned here to
M. macintoshi
sp. nov.
Whereas the locality stated by Pettibone (1976) for specimens accessed as BMNH : 1924: 7: 21: 12 was South Africa (off Cape Point Lighthouse, 860 m depth), the label inside the vial containing these specimens states South Africa ( Cape of Good Hope, 300 –500 fathoms = 540–900 m ), as included in the Material examined section in this publication.

Etymology. This species is dedicated to W. C. McIntosh, who described many polychaete species, including the first species of
Macellicephala ,
M. mirabilis ( McIntosh, 1885 )
and who also collected the specimens upon which the description of
M. macintoshi
sp. nov.
is based.
